If both brexpiprazole and nabilone have not been helpful,i would begin by tapering and then stopping nabilone over the course of 1 week, waiting 3 days and then tapering and stopping brexpiprazole over the course of another week.After the taper of brexpiprazole you can proceed with increasing quetiapine as below.If both nabilone and brexpiprazole have been beneficial,you can simply proceed with quetiapine increase right away Quetiapine can be increased every 4 days in 12.5 mg increments to either the daytime or nighttime dose,depending on the pattern of symptoms.It seems PRN's are mostly given in the mornings,so increasing the morning dose first may be ideal.For now i recommend a maximum of 100 mg of quetiapine daily from ALL sources (including PRN's).The titration should be based on tolerability,with particular attention paid to oversedation risks.Potential side effects include sedation,orthostatic hypotension,falls,weight gain,hyperglycemia,and hyperlipidemia.Quetiapine may cause extrapyramidal symptoms though has lower risk of this compared to other antipsychotics.There is a rare risk of neuroleptic malignant syndrome or seizure,and in patients with dementia there is a small increase in risk of mortality. In addition,if not recently done,an ECG is recommended prior to starting quetiapine given the risk of QT interval. For monitoring lipid profile,fasting glucose,HbA1c,weight,BMI and blood pressure can be checked every 3 months,if within goals of care. The switch from quetiapine can be done by tapering quetiapine in 12.5 mg increments every 4 days,while simultaneously increasing risperidone by 0.125 mg every 4 days.The maximum daily dose should be 1 mg from all sources.Risperidone can be given BID or as a single evening dose,depending on the timing of symptoms.Risk are similar to those stated above,with a higher risk of EPS and lower risk of sedation.
